1.brief: properly, to bend or stoop in kindness to an inferior; to favor, bestow; causatively to implore (i.e. move to favor by petition)

gods in the ordinary sense; but specifically used (in the plural thus, especially with the article) of the supreme God; occasionally applied by way of deference to magistrates; and sometimes as a superlative
kindness; by implication (towards God) piety; rarely (by opposition) reproof, or (subject.) beauty
compassion (in the plural); by extension, the womb (as cherishing the fetus); by implication, a maiden
properly, to stroke or rub; by implication, to erase; also to smooth (as if with oil), i.e. grease or make fat; also to touch, i.e. reach to

2.brief: to trample; hence, to wash (properly, by stamping with the feet), whether literal (including the fulling process) or figurative
an offence (sometimes habitual sinfulness), and its penalty, occasion, sacrifice, or expiation; also (concretely) an offender
to be pure (physical sound, clear, unadulterated; Levitically, uncontaminated; morally, innocent or holy)

3.brief: (by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed

to know (properly, to ascertain by seeing); used in a great variety of senses, figuratively, literally, euphemistically and inferentially (including observation, care, recognition; and causatively, instruction, designation, punishment, etc.)
an offence (sometimes habitual sinfulness), and its penalty, occasion, sacrifice, or expiation; also (concretely) an offender
a front, i.e. part opposite; specifically a counterpart, or mate; usually (adverbial, especially with preposition) over against or before
properly, continuance (as indefinite extension); but used only (attributively as adjective) constant (or adverbially, constantly); ellipt. the regular (daily) sacrifice

4.brief: properly, separation; by implication, a part of the body, branch of atree, bar forcarrying; figuratively, chief of a city; especially (with prepositional prefix) as an adverb, apart, only, besides
properly, to miss; hence (figuratively and generally) to sin; by inference, to forfeit, lack, expiate, repent, (causatively) lead astray, condemn
bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)
an eye (literally or figuratively); by analogy, a fountain (as the eye of the landscape)
to do or make, in the broadest sense and widest application
properly, heed, i.e. purpose; used only adverbially, on account of (as a motive or an aim), teleologically, in order that
to be (causatively, make) right (in a moral or forensic sense)
perhaps properly, to arrange; but used figuratively (of words), to speak; rarely (in a destructive sense) to subdue
to be translucent; figuratively, to be innocent
to judge, i.e. pronounce sentence (for or against); by implication, to vindicate or punish; by extenssion, to govern; passively, to litigate (literally or figuratively)

5.brief: properly, to twist or whirl (in a circular or spiral manner), i.e. (specifically) to dance, to writhe in pain (especially of parturition) or fear; figuratively, to wait, to pervert
probably to be hot; figuratively, to conceive
a mother (as the bond of the family); in a wide sense (both literally and figuratively (like father))

6.brief: properly, to incline to; by implication (literally but rarely) to bend; figuratively, to be pleased with, desire
(in the plural only) the kidneys (as being covered); hence (figuratively) the inmost thought
to stop up; by implication, to repair; figuratively, to keep secret

to know (properly, to ascertain by seeing); used in a great variety of senses, figuratively, literally, euphemistically and inferentially (including observation, care, recognition; and causatively, instruction, designation, punishment, etc.)

7.brief: properly, to miss; hence (figuratively and generally) to sin; by inference, to forfeit, lack, expiate, repent, (causatively) lead astray, condemn
to be pure (physical sound, clear, unadulterated; Levitically, uncontaminated; morally, innocent or holy)
to trample; hence, to wash (properly, by stamping with the feet), whether literal (including the fulling process) or figurative
to be (or become) white;  to make bricks

8.brief: to hear intelligently (often with implication of attention, obedience, etc.; causatively, to tell, etc.)
properly, to spin round (under the influence of any violent emotion), i.e. usually rejoice, or (as cringing) fear
a bone (as strong); by extension, the body; figuratively, the substance, i.e. (as pron.) selfsame

9.brief: to hide (by covering), literally or figuratively
the face (as the part that turns); used in a great variety of applications (literally and figuratively); also (with prepositional prefix) as a preposition (before, etc.)
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
properly, to stroke or rub; by implication, to erase; also to smooth (as if with oil), i.e. grease or make fat; also to touch, i.e. reach to

10.brief: the heart; also used (figuratively) very widely for the feelings, the will and even the intellect; likewise for the centre of anything
pure (in a physical, chemical, ceremonial or moral sense)
(absolutely) to create; (qualified) to cut down (a wood), select, feed (as formative processes)

gods in the ordinary sense; but specifically used (in the plural thus, especially with the article) of the supreme God; occasionally applied by way of deference to magistrates; and sometimes as a superlative

wind; by resemblance breath, i.e. a sensible (or even violent) exhalation; figuratively, life, anger, unsubstantiality; by extension, a region of the sky; by resemblance spirit, but only of a rational being (including its expression and functions)

properly, to be erect (i.e. stand perpendicular); hence (causatively) to set up, in a great variety of applications, whether literal (establish, fix, prepare, apply), or figurative (appoint, render sure, proper or prosperous)
to be new; causatively, to rebuild
properly, the nearest part, i.e. the center, whether literal, figurative or adverbial (especially with preposition)

11.brief: not (the qualified negation, used as a deprecative); once (Job 24:25) as a noun, nothing
to throw out, down or away (literally or figuratively)
the face (as the part that turns); used in a great variety of applications (literally and figuratively); also (with prepositional prefix) as a preposition (before, etc.)

wind; by resemblance breath, i.e. a sensible (or even violent) exhalation; figuratively, life, anger, unsubstantiality; by extension, a region of the sky; by resemblance spirit, but only of a rational being (including its expression and functions)
a sacred place or thing; rarely abstract, sanctity
not (the qualified negation, used as a deprecative); once (Job 24:25) as a noun, nothing
to take (in the widest variety of applications)
properly, a part of; hence (prepositionally), from or out of in many senses

12.brief: to turn back (hence, away) transitively or intransitively, literally or figuratively (not necessarily with the idea of return to the starting point); generally to retreat; often adverbial, again

wind; by resemblance breath, i.e. a sensible (or even violent) exhalation; figuratively, life, anger, unsubstantiality; by extension, a region of the sky; by resemblance spirit, but only of a rational being (including its expression and functions)
properly, voluntary, i.e. generous; hence, magnanimous; as noun, a grandee (sometimes a tyrant)
to prop (literally or figuratively); reflexively, to lean upon or take hold of (in a favorable or unfavorable sense)

13.brief: properly, to goad, i.e. (by implication) to teach (the rod being an Oriental incentive)
to break away (from just authority), i.e. trespass, apostatize, quarrel
a road (as trodden); figuratively, a course of life or mode of action, often adverb
a criminal, or one accounted guilty
near, with or among; often in general, to
to turn back (hence, away) transitively or intransitively, literally or figuratively (not necessarily with the idea of return to the starting point); generally to retreat; often adverbial, again

14.brief: to snatch away, whether in a good or a bad sense
blood (as that which when shed causes death) of man or an animal; by analogy, the juice of the grape; figuratively (especially in the plural) bloodshed (i.e. drops of blood)

gods in the ordinary sense; but specifically used (in the plural thus, especially with the article) of the supreme God; occasionally applied by way of deference to magistrates; and sometimes as a superlative

rightness (abstractly), subjectively (rectitude), objectively (justice), morally (virtue) or figuratively (prosperity)

15.brief: the Lord (used as a proper name of God only)
the lip (as a natural boundary); by implication, language; by analogy, a margin (of a vessel, water, cloth, etc.)
to open wide (literally or figuratively); specifically, to loosen, begin, plough, carve
the mouth (as the means of blowing), whether literal or figurative (particularly speech); specifically edge, portion or side; adverbially (with preposition) according to

properly, to front, i.e. stand boldly out opposite; by implication (causatively), to manifest; figuratively, to announce (always by word of mouth to one present); specifically, to expose, predict, explain, praise

not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles

properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
